channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Syria Talks Take Tentative Step Forward Despite New Attacks
item.description: The United Nations mediator in the Syria war was meeting with the opposition delegation in Geneva amid new attacks and deprivation on the battlefield.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Staffan de Mistura, second from left, the United Nations mediator in the Syria war, sat opposite Syria’s main opposition group during peace talks on Monday in Geneva.

item.title: African Union Issues Biting Report on Crisis in South Sudan
item.description: The nine-page report blames government forces and rebels for the declining humanitarian situation, in which starvation, lack of government oversight and violence reign.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Soldiers in the South Sudanese Army in Eastern Equatoria State last year. The report form the African Union has blamed the rebels and government forces for human atrocities.

item.title: How Moon Dust Languished in a Downing Street Cupboard
item.description: The moon dust’s fate was revealed by Britain’s National Archives, which released 178 pages of correspondence on the subject going back 30 years.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS
item.media:description: From left, Commander Neil Armstrong and his fellow astronauts, Michael Collins and Edwin E. (Buzz) Aldrin Jr., were welcomed back to Earth by President Richard M. Nixon.

item.title: Taliban Bombing Kills at Least 20 at Kabul Police Station
item.description: The new attack on the capital came as American officials gave a grim new estimate of Afghan casualties in last year’s fighting.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:description: Security forces at the site of a suicide attack in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Monday.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Peru’s Possible Prison Presidency
item.description: A former general is running for the top job in April’s election even as he faces trial for the army’s 1988 assassination of a journalist.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: SONIA GOLDENBERG

item.title: At War Blog: Seven Marathons in Seven Days, Crossing Each Finish Line for Fellow Marines
item.description: Marine Corps Captain Calum Rammhe, a longtime marathon runner, ran seven marathons on seven continents in seven days to raise money for a charity that supports wounded Marines and their families. It also let him reflect on why running is more than a hobby for him.
item.dc:creator: CALUM RAMM
item.media:description: Capt. Calum Ramm at the Antarctica Logistics and Expedition base camp on Union Glacier. The tents in the back were the team’s lodging.

item.title: Benoît Violier, Top French-Swiss Chef, Dies at 44
item.description: Mr. Violier ran the Restaurant de l’Hôtel de Ville in Switzerland, which was named the world’s best in December. The police said his death appeared to have been a suicide.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Benoît Violier in 2013. The French-Swiss chef was found dead on Sunday at his home in Crissier, near Lausanne, Switzerland.

item.title: Memo From China: Light Government Touch Lets China’s Hui Practice Islam in the Open
item.description: For the Muslims in the Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region, there are fewer limitations on religion. “Life for the Hui is very good,” an imam said.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hui students before evening prayers at the Banqiao Daotang Islamic School in Wuzhong, China, in October.

item.title: U.N. Rights Chief Urges Turkey to Investigate Shooting of Civilians
item.description: Two were said to have been killed when troops appeared to open fire on an unarmed group about 10 days ago. The wounded included a journalist who filmed the episode.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, at a news conference in Geneva on Monday.

item.title: John Kerry Urges Syrian Factions Not to Squander U.N. Talks
item.description: The major world powers — as well as regional actors that have fueled the war — have all given their blessings for talks to take place, but they want different things.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: An antigovernment fighter hiding in the rebel-controlled area of Arbeen, near Damascus, Syria.

item.title: Sinosphere: Exploitation of Endangered Species Feared as China Revisits Wildlife Law
item.description: A proposed revision makes explicit that endangered species are “natural resources” that can be legally bred in captivity for commercial purposes.
item.category: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species
item.dc:creator: SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen/The Washington Post, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Siberian Tiger Park in Harbin, China. Conservationists warn that proposed changes to the Wildlife Protection Law could make it easier to breed endangered species for commercial purposes.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Italian-Iranian Hall of Mirrors
item.description: The West has not capitulated by hiding the Capitoline nudes. But Italy has again failed the test of seriousness.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Don’t Shoot the Messenger, Israel
item.description: Lashing out at critics will not resolve an untenable occupation.
item.dc:creator: BAN KI-MOON
item.media:description: A Palestinian man protesting Israeli settlements in the West Bank.

item.title: Israel Approves Prayer Space at Western Wall for Non-Orthodox Jews
item.description: The decision by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s cabinet was seen as a victory for American Jewish leaders and Jewish women who struggled for years for inclusion.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Anat Hoffman, left, of Women of the Wall, said the decision acknowledged “that there is more than one way to be Jewish.”

item.title: Saudi Coalition in Yemen Announces Inquiry Into Bombings
item.description: Responding to criticism of its bombings in Yemen, which rights groups have called war crimes, the Saudi-led military coalition there announced the formation of an investigative committee.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Syria Peace Talks Inch Ahead as Bombings Near Damascus Continue
item.description: Islamic State social media accounts said the group was responsible for the attack, which came as opposing sides of the Syrian conflict were gathered in Geneva for talks.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Residents and pro-government military members at the site of the bombing, near a Shiite shrine south of Damascus.

item.title: U.S. Broadens Fight Against ISIS With Attacks in Afghanistan
item.description: The operations followed President Obama’s decision to expand the authority of American commanders to attack a new branch of the militant group in Afghanistan.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Iraqi pro-government forces clashed with Islamic State fighters on the outskirts of Ramadi on Sunday.

item.title: New Technologies Give Government Ample Means to Track Suspects, Study Finds
item.description: Fears that encrypted communication will prevent agencies from tracking terrorists are overstated, according to a study that included current and former intelligence officials.
item.category: Berkman Center for Internet and Society
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:credit: Kevin hagen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, and other Justice Department officials have said moves by technology firms to encrypt data have choked off critical ways to monitor suspects.

item.title: Microcephaly, Spotlighted by Zika Virus, Has Long Afflicted and Mystified
item.description: Each year, an estimated 25,000 babies in the United States receive a diagnosis of microcephaly, an abnormally small head, but prognoses are hard to predict.
item.category: National Institute of Child Health and Human Development
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE SAINT LOUIS
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alainah Therrien, who is 15 months old, in the lap of her grandmother, Heather Crossman, with her great grandmother, Rosalie Wherity, in Dennis Port, Mass. Alainah was given a diagnosis of microcephaly before birth.

item.title: Swedish Police Foiled Planned Attack on Immigrants in Stockholm
item.description: When scores of masked men, many of them gang members, descended on the center of Stockholm on Friday to terrorize young migrants, the police were waiting for them.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA ANDERSON
item.media:credit: Marcus Ericsson/Tt News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathered in Norrmalmstorg square in Stockholm on Saturday to show their disapproval of an anti-immigration movement.
